TOKYO - A popular manga comic is setting off a public debate in Japan about the health effects of radiation following the Fukushima nuclear disaster - so much so the publisher issued a special edition Monday .
The April 28 issue of Oishinbo , by Tetsu Kariya , depicted a character getting a nosebleed after visiting Fukushima Dai - ichi nuclear plant .

Three of its reactors sank into meltdowns after the March 2011 tsunami , and radiation contaminates nearby towns .
Local governments say the manga comic 's portrayal fosters unfounded fears , even discrimination against Fukushima .

Big Comic Spirits magazine added a special section in its Monday 's issue with criticism and input it had received on Oishinbo , including views from medical experts .
